last_replies.com:
>>26082495
A well built, comfortable car that is decently quick. The interiors aren’t amazing but mechanically the cars are put together alright. Keep up with maintenance and try not to idle it too much. The Hemis don’t oil the cam and lifters so great at low rpms so excessive idling can lead to the needle bearings in the lifters taking a shit and wiping out the cam. Use up the stock 245s and throw on some 275s or bigger if you can. My ScatPack has the 20”x9” rims so 275 is about as big as you can go before you start getting into tire wear problems assuming that car will also have a 9” rim. Get used to the boat comments from Mustang and Camaro owners, they’re just mad they don’t have useable back seats or rear visibility.

>>26068883
Mitsubishi Motors completely abandoned RWD cars with the exception of the Starion in the 1980s. This would be one of the many decisions that would bleed the brand over the next few decades.
When the big three of Japan decided to come out with their bespoke luxury brands, Mitsubishi decided there was no need for this despite having basically no clout in the American market, they made fleet and commuter vehicles. This combined with the pathetic 3.0 V6 meant the gussies up Galant known as the Sigma was a failure.
They also gradually fucked up their sports car lineup in the states as well. The DSM cars, Chrysler's FWD sports cars, and the captive import Starion (Chrysler Conquest), occupied slightly varying price levels but were essentially in competition with each other in the same showrooms.
The GTO/3000GT used a twin-turbo version of the 6G72 3.0 V6 in the highest trims. We know now that even this engine struggled to power the AWD system of the over 3500 lb car which wasn't helped by the two turbochargers. What's stranger is that the 6G74 3.5 V6 was dropped in multiple Mitsubishi vehicles, SUVs and sedans, and was able to approach the twin-turbo 6G72 in power in NA form.
During the height of the Fast and Furious tuner hype, Mitsubishi cut corners and made the third generation Eclipse FWD only, but let you have a V6.
The company would spend the 2000s and 2010s producing shitty commuter cars for the states, the market they invested so much into entering through the Chrysler partnership. By the 2010s they were essentially a second class Jap brand like Suzuki and Isuzu.

"Safe" is relative.
Do the suspension work as intended?
Do the brakes work properly?

How fast can I go before the car starts death rattling via vibrations?

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
I just bought a D16A6 for my hatch and I took it apart to rebuild before putting in the car.

So far everything is decent, the cylinders still have their crosshatch and I'm thinking about not overboring and just putting it back together, however I did decide to measure it with a bore gauge.

The outside cylinders (1 and 4) are all good enough and within spec (taper and out-of-round is less than 0.05 mm and the bore is not larger than 75.07mm in any point)

Problem is with cylinders 2 and 3. At the top measuring location (closest to the head) in the non-thrust direction my bore gauge is reading a diameter of 74.92 mm (the nominal diameter is 75.00-75.02 mm). I've never seen this before and I still can't even wrap my head around how it's possible for a cylinder to shrink. In the thrust side the diameter is 75.05 or so which is normal and then down the bore it's also normal. It's just in the non-thrust axis at the top that the cylinders are smaller than nominal diameter. I am not measuring at the absolute top where there is carbon deposit, I'm measuring below the deposits.

Anyone have any idea what's happening here? I checked this shit like 5 times and I'm sure it's not my tools because cylinders 1 and 4 are fine as well as 2 and 3 as you get down the bore. Should I take it to a machine shop to get checked? Or just overbore it to be safe? Pistons are looking pretty good which is why I don't want to overbore it if I don't have to. Is there any possibility that the block is warped in such a way to affect cylinders 2 and 3 and squish them? Any help I will be grateful

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
That is an odd one. Maybe it overheated in the past and warped but I think that's unlikely but its the only thing I can think of.

Have you done a compression test?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>26083154
No, I took it apart before that, but the weirdest thing is that when you go 1 inch down the bore everything is normal

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>26080726
It's possible that the cylinder came undersized. I've gotten measurements similar to those in Honda engines, where the cylinders 2 and 3 happen to be undersized for some reason.

last_replies.com:
>>26083199
I spoke to my machinist just now and he also said that because of heat cycling the out of round condition not only widens the thrust direction but shrinks the other direction in the process, just gonna machine it 0.25 over

last_replies.name: z31
last_replies.com:
>>26083378
ah yeah, suspension bolts are def something you want more power for. I have nothing but great things to say about milwaukee for impact driver, for suspension the stubby drivers do wonders in getting to hard to reach places.

last_replies.name: Bepis
last_replies.com:
>>26083389
This about the power tools, don’t go buying a ratchet and stubby impact and all this BS right away, those are time saving tools for people who do a lot of work, you don’t need them to get the job done.

Focus on the basic hand tools first. And when it comes to power tools, a drill + impact driver kit are good first steps for any DIYer. Stick a socket adapter on the impact driver and it will do the same thing as any 3/8” impact wrench. And when you get into wrenching more, then think about a 1/2” impact wrench to speed up wheels and to help with stubborn large fasteners.

For hand tools, most of the mid range stuff comes out of the same couple Taiwanese factories so you can’t go wrong if you find a good deal on Husky or Kobalt or Craftsman. Tekton is solid. I like Gearwrench because they add a couple small touches on some of their tools that are good for /o/ stuff. Those Milwaukee wrenches are newer, they look nice but they’re expensive for Asian made tools. When the socket sets are on sale for 50% off, it looks like a good buy, but at full price you could get a premium US made set like SK for only a few bucks more.

Also when you start getting to the power tools, can’t go wrong with Ryobi. Milwaukee has a great selection but is going to cost you. Meanwhile Ryobi has a huge lineup of DIYer tier tools that should be fine. The newest Ryobi HP stuff is like 90% the performance of Milwaukee for half the price, and if there’s a cordless tool you want but will only be using once or twice a year as a DIYer, you can get the cheaper Ryobi non-HP version. Once you get stuck on the Milwaukee battery platform, you will be paying $$$ for tools meant to run 40+ hours a week and are overkill for a weekender.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>26082356
You don't know what you're talking about.

It's 200 - 500 miles for each stage.
The rally goes on for 16 days. Depending on the year, the total rally distance is 6000 to 8500 miles. That's an average of 450 miles a day, for 16 days straight.

The privateers are the true MVPs. They race all day, fix their broken/worn out shit at camp that evening by themselves, and maybe, just maybe sleep a couple hours before the next stage. That's only if they don't delay, get lost, or break down on the stage. It's not unusual to have participants show up late at night, early next morning, or not show up at all and need to be rescued.

Let's not forget navigation. Depending on the stage, sometimes the participants have to navigate their own way through the terrain, occasionally at night. Crossing dunes, mountains, valleys, spurs, depressions, jungles, marshes, boulder/rock fields, ravines, etc etc.

threads.com: Hey guys. The Ruckus is my first combustion vehicle. Have had it for a year and a half. Recently tried to install a CDI and the little blue splicer plastic thing caused a circuit bleed and killed the battery. Removed the CDI, went back to stock. Rode fine for a week and then battery died again. Kickstarted, worked, rode for a week. Now battery's kaput. I charged it at the wall with a Battery Tender, and the charge doesn't keep for more than 24h. Checked voltage when it was dead, 11V. Is it possible that when I reconnected wires, I introduced a new bleed? Is the battery perhaps just dead-dead? My friend suggested checking the alternator; the lights brighten when I rev the engine and he claims this shouldn't be (but has no experience with bikes). Really stumped.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>26078331
>ruckus is first combustion
Are you RETARDED

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>26079678
Ruckus is impossible to kick start cold with dead battery because it needs to be primed by the electric fuel pump. If you don’t hear a few clicks from under the floor board when you turn the key, then it’s not being primed.

If you can let it trickle charge for a few min before kick starting, there might be enough power to prime.

You can get a cheap battery on Amazon for like $25usd. Buy a good battery and a good trickle charger if you can, and never leave it in the cold. I would also keep it totally stock, there’s really nothing to be gained performance wise. Except maybe an led headlight.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>26082047
>keep it totally stock
That's the plan. I learned my lesson. The CDI caused a lot of weird problems that I couldn't figure out. Most importantly, it was killing the engine. I know it wasn't a rev issue even though I'd been waiting on the tachometer in the mail, because the engine never sounded like it had surpassed the old peak. I only rode it very gently at low speed a handful of times while testing it. The engine was dying as it revved down, specifically. Whenever I'd roll towards a stop, or revved below 3/4 throttle, in both cases only after running the bike for 10 minutes or so, it would die. Couldn't figure it out, but the problem was immediately fixed after I got rid of the CDI. One of the plugs on the wires was a casualty though, and I had to carefully solder it back on, which is why I was worried there might be a circuit bleed. I had thought that circuit bleeds have to be discharging through an obvious ground path. The blue plastic splice lock thing that came with the CDI didn't seem to do that and still killed the battery. Someone above suggested it might've been the CDI itself pulling energy from the battery. I don't know.

threads.com:
What are some rare engines?

Audi only made one 50(?) q7 with the v12 tdi. Only car it was put into. What a bunch of morons. Who else does this?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
The engine was unusual in being an opposed piston engine where each horizontal cylinder contains 2 pistons, one at each end, that move in opposition to each other. Even more unusually, both sets of pistons drove only a 1 crankshaft; most opposed piston engines have a separate crankshaft at each end of the cylinder. The TS3 engine used a 1 crankshaft beneath the cylinders, each piston driving it through a connecting rod, a rocker lever and a 2nd connecting rod. The crankshaft had 6 crankpins and there were 6 rockers.

The engine was a 2-stroke, compression-ignition diesel engine with uniflow-ported cylinders. Scavenging was performed by a Roots blower which was mounted on the front of the engine and driven by a long quill shaft from a chain drive at the rear of the engine.

The engine has a compression ratio of 9.20:1. These combine to provide a maximum power of 287 kW (390 PS; 385 hp) at 6,300 rpm and maximum torque of 490 N⋅m (361 lb⋅ft) at 4,500 rpm.
